metadata.case_name: Kays Construction Co. Pvt. Ltd. v. Respondents Nos. 1 to 4

facts.text: Appellant Company is successor of Kays Construction Company owned by Mr. H. M. Khosla, who stopped business as unprofitable before new company took over business and some workmen.

Industrial dispute before Allahabad Industrial Tribunal (Sugar); award dated January 31, 1958 directing reinstatement of old workmen in Annexure, continuity of service, and 50% back wages due to peculiar features.
Workmen claimed back wages under s.6-H(1) U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 before Labour Commissioner (delegate of State Government).
Appellant objected: some workmen accepted employment with appellant or elsewhere, some not parties to dispute or died, exact days of unemployment not determined.
Labour Commissioner issued certificate to Collector on July 21, 1958 for Rs. 1,06,588-6-6.
Objections filed to State Government; Regional Conciliation Officer ordered to verify claims.
Labour Commissioner issued second certificate on September 9, 1959 for Rs. 50,654-9-6 as certainly due, balance after verification.
Collector passed order on September 10, 1959 communicated to Chief Mechanical Engineer, N.E. Railway to pay from appellant's security deposit.
Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 on November 2, 1959 to quash orders dated September 9 and 10, 1959 and release attached property.
Single Judge Broome J. allowed writ on condition of security, quashed orders holding claims under s.6-H(2) needed for computation.
Division Bench reversed Broome J. on March 15, 1962 in Special Appeal No. 574 of 1960.
High Court declined certificate under Art. 133 on May 9, 1962 in Supreme Court Appeal No. 53 of 1962.
Supreme Court granted special leave; appeal against judgment to be dismissed, no need for other appeal.

legal_issues.text: Whether claims for back wages under the Tribunal award fall under s.6-H(1) as 'money due' or require determination under s.6-H(2) as 'benefit capable of being computed in terms of money'.

petitioner_arguments.text: Exact amount of back wages requires determination by Labour Court under s.6-H(2) before certificate under s.6-H(1); analogous to s.33C Industrial Disputes Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: M.S.S. Transports v. Rajaram; Sesamusa Sugar Works v. State of Bihar; Shri Amarsinghji Mills v. Nagarashua

petitioner_arguments.text: Proceedings under s.6-H(1) premature without computation of exact days unemployed.

respondent_arguments.text: Back wages are 'money due' under s.6-H(1); s.6-H(2) for benefits like free quarters, not earned wages requiring mere arithmetical calculation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.S. Shetty v. Bharat Nidhi Ltd.; distinguished Kasturi Sons v. N. Salivatesaram; Punjab National Bank v. Kharbunda

court_reasoning.text: s.6-H analogous to s.33C Industrial Disputes Act and s.20 Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act; first sub-section for 'money due' like back wages, second for benefits not yet money (e.g., free quarters) requiring computation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Back wages involve arithmetical calculation covered by s.6-H(1); objections verified for satisfaction under (1), not determination under (2).

court_reasoning.text: Division Bench correctly distinguished precedents; appellant's obstructions are verification under s.6-H(1), not computation under (2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Antithesis between 'money due' and 'benefit computed in terms of money' marks operation of sub-sections.

holdings.text: Claims for back wages are 'money due' under s.6-H(1) U.P. Industrial Disputes Act; no need for prior determination under s.6-H(2).

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogous provision for recovery of money due or computed benefits

outcome.summary: Appeal against Allahabad High Court judgment dated March 15, 1962 dismissed; no need to decide appeal against certificate refusal order. Division Bench judgment upheld allowing recovery under s.6-H(1).

key_quotes.text: "As a result of my findings above, I hold that management of Messrs. Kays Construction Co. Private Limited, Allahabad, are required to reinstate the old workmen given in the Annexure... paid only 50 per cent, of their back wages."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: Extract from Tribunal award central to dispute

key_quotes.text: "a case such as the present, where the money due is back wages for the period of unemployment is covered by the first sub-section and not the second."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding distinguishing sub-sections of s.6-H

key_quotes.text: The contrast between 'money due' on the one hand and a benefit which is not money due but which can become so after the money equivalent is determined on the other, marks out the areas of the operation of the two sub-sections.
key_quotes.speaker: court
